This Company's system of submarine telegraph

communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINE, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m., a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: BIRTHS

div.head: THE CRETAN QUESTION.
div.p: To-day the Greek battleship Psara is to return to Crete bringing Prince George's successor in the High Commissionership, M. Zaimis. It is now eight years since, after more than half a century of almost continuous insurrection under Turkish rule, the island of Crete, having been taken in hand by the four Protecting Powers—Great Britain, Russia, France, and Italy—was by them constituted a separate State, subject, however, on the one hand to the formal suzerainty of the Porte, and on the other hand to the rule of a High Commissioner to be appointed by themselves. The second son of the King of the Hellenes was the first High Commissioner; so well did he succeed that his re appointment after his first three years' office came almost as a matter of course. Peace and order, however, were not destined to endure in the island. Within the past few years there has come to be more and more clearly defined a radical opposition between the aspirations of the majority of the Cretans and the policy of the Protecting Powers. The Cretans—so far, at least, as they are represented in the National Assembly—desire annexation to Greece. As part and parcel of this they desire the removal of the real control exercised by the four Powers and enforced by the presence of their troops, and the abolition of the formal suzerainty of the Porte. Time after time the Cretan Assembly has passed resolutions demanding oreven declaring as a fact the union of the island to the kingdom of Greece. Time after time the Protecting Powers have met this demand with a direct negative. Prince George's resignation of the High Commissionership is a direct recognition of the incompatibility between the national aspirations of which he made himself the spokesman and the policy of the Powers who set him in office. His successor, M. Zaimis, is, of course, also a Greek, and is no doubt under the circumstances one of the best men who could have been chosen for the position. M. Zaimis comes of a house which is one of the most distinguished in the political life of modern Greece. He is himself a statesman of the highest position. He is, in virtue of a partial concession of the Powers on September 17, nominated not by the Powers themselves, but by the King of the Hellenes, after consultation with their reprentatives, and subject to their assent. M Zaimis, in fact, represents nearly all that the Cretans might be expected to want, except the one thing that they are known in fact to want—annexation to Greece.

Why, then, asks the "Morning Post," do the Powers not go this one step further and allow the desired union of the island to the country to which they allow such influence in the choice of a ruler? A variety of reasons may be and are given, Union would mean the abolition of the formal suzerainty still retained by Turkey, and would therefore not be accomplished without a protest from that quarter. Again, the affairs of Crete are mysteriously confused with those of Macedonia. Bulgaria would demand compensation in the latter quarter if Greece were allowed to enlarge itself by the annexation of Crete in the Mediterranean. A third reason, and one of quite another sort, is to be found in the necessity for preserving in the island the peace to secure which the Powers intervened in the first instance. In the words of the Note addressed by them to the Cretan Assembly in July last, "every step towards the realisation of the national aspirations must necessarily be subordinated to the establishment and the maintenance of order and a stable régime." In other words, the Powers cannot,' and will not, withdraw their control in favour of Greece unless and until they are convinced that this will not mean opening the door to insurrection and civil warfare. In so far as there is any good reason for supposing that Greece could not with the goodwill of the Cretans govern them at least as peacefully as the Powers can against their will, this last argument is worth considering. But unless this supposition can be reasonably made—and it clearly needs a great deal of proving —it must be admitted that the arguments against allowing union to Greece are rather weak. If the Powers should ever themselves become convinced of the necessity for this union they clearly could and would disregard the possible protests of Turkey and Bulgaria. The root of the difficulty probably is simply that the Powers by their constitution cannot easily be convinced in favour of any positive action. The dissent of any one of them may baulk the harmonious action of all. Therefore, like all other associations requiring unanimity for action, they tend to inaction and to letting things drift.

div.head:
H.H. THE KHEDIVE.
DEPARTURE FROM CONSTANTINOPLE
div.p: His Highness the Khedive left Constantinople to day for Alexandria on board the Mahrousaa, and should arrive at that port on Tuesday. The refitted yacht was greatly admired on her arrival here. She has been converted into a magnificent and speedy vessel.
The Khedive has left for Alexandria on board the Mahroussa. (Reuter.)

div.head: Minieh Moudirleh Council
div.p: Said Bey Galal has been elected as member of the Moudirieh Council, Minieh, by 129 votes against 35.

div.head: The Suppression of Gambling.
div.p: Three days ago, the Cairo police raided a gambling den belonging to a Greek at Darb Mustapha, Cairo, and confiseated the paraphernalia and money.

div.head: Cairo to Alexandria Trains.
div.p: We are advised by the secretariat of the Egyptian State Railways that trains Nos. 90 and 91 from Alexandria to Cairo and vice- versa, viz. the mid-day restaurant car trains, will continue to stop daily at Sidi Gaber.

div.head: Nisf Shaaban Ceremony.
div.p: The ceremony of Nisf Shaaban will be held to-morrow evening at the Citadel Mosque, Cairo, under the presidency of Prince Mohamed Aly, representing the Khedive. A large number of Ulema, officials, and notables will attend the ceremony.

div.head: The Late Mrs. Alderson.
div.p: The "Dead March in Saul" was played by the organist of All Saints' Church. Ramleh, at the close of the morning service yesterday, as a token of the high respect in which Mrs. Alderson was held by the residents of Alexandria's popular suburb.

div.head: English Printing In Egypt
div.p: Messrs. Whitehead, Morris, and Co. (Egypt) Limited have transferred their Alexandria offices from 6, Ramleh Boulevard to 14, Sesostris- street. This compauy will shortly open a large printing establishment in Attarin-street, and the machinery is already on its way out.

div.head: All Saints Church, Ramleh.
div.p: Arrangements have been made by which the Rev. C. H. V Gollmer will take charge of All Saints' Church during the month of October, when the Snnday services will be: Holy Communion 8 30 a.m. morning service 11 am. children's service 3.30 p.m., evening service 6.30 p m. The chaplain for the winter months will be the Rev. A. H Ellaby, M.A., who is expected to arrive the first week in November.

div.head: School of Veterinary Medicine
div.p: The following is the result of the entrance examination for the School of Veterinary Medicine held on the 27th Sentembor 1906: Admitted to the school. Ahmed Mohamed Kamel, Ismail Aboul Ela, Mohamed Said, Mohamed Aref Nagati, Mohamed Ahmed Abou Shohbah, Aly Selim, Mohamed Aboul Azm, Ahmed Shaker.

div.head: Turkish Contraband.
div.p: Strante things are contraband in Turkey. Novels such as the "Swiss Family Robinson," because the dog is named Turk ; dictionaries containing the words 'elder' and 'brother,' as Abdul Hamid usurped the throne from his elder brother ; and works of chemistry containing the term H.O, which could but mean Hamid—Second—Zero.

div.head: Pharaoh's Dogs.
div.p: The "County Gentleman" states that the latest foreign breed of dog which has made its appearance among us is the Eastern greyhound. This species is, and has been from time immemorial, the hunting dog of the Eastern plains, and, making allowances for the artistic attainments of those early periods, we find representations of him which are almost identical with the dogs of to-day on the monuments and tombs of ancient Egypt.

div.head: The Sardinian's Encounter.
div.p: The Ellerman Line steamship Sardinian while proceeding down Channel yesterday week with a large complement of passengers from Liverpool to Alexandria, observed a vessel off the Smalls signalling for assistance. This proved to be the steamer Naraja from Valencia to Liverpool with fruit. Her machinery was disabled. The Sardinian took her in tow back to Holyhead, arriving there the same evening, and after placing the Naraja safely in port proceeded on her way.

div.head: Walker and Melmarachi.
div.p: The branch which Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi opened on Saturday afternoon at Ramleh is certainly a model institution. It will supply the long felt want of an up-to-date store for our fashionable quarter. The shop is in the block to the left of the Casino entrance. It is furnished with a view both to artistic effect and practical business requirements. Both on Saturday and yesterday the shop was well patronised, and there in every reason to believe that it will do a flourishing trade.

div.head:
THE NILE FLOOD.
RECORD COTTON CROP.
IMPORTANT NOTE.
div.p: Mr. Webb has issued a note on the state of the Nile flood. During the first part of August the flood was, although better than the series of low floods experienced during the past twelve years, somewhat late in its arrival. The level reached at Assouan were well below the average for thirty years past. The levels of the Southern gauges, however, indicated that an improvement would take place, and during the second half of August the level was satisfactory, though still below the average of thirty years. During September a still more satisfactory level was maintained, the average of thirty years being surpassed. On the 8th September the maximum gauge at Assouan was R. L. 92.68, (15 pics and 20 kinats). On the 14th September it was 16 centimetres below the maximum average of thirty years. The usual fall has now commenced, and will continue. Considerable difficulty was experienced at the beginning of August in meeting very heavy demands for irrigation of dhurra lands and the cotton crop simultaneously. This, however, diminished before the middle of August and finally ceased before the month was out.
The cotton crop promises to be the largest yet recorded.
Irrigation of basin lands in Upper Egypt began between the 10th and 15th August and will generally be completed by the end of this month.

The levels for basin irrigation have been generally satisfactory as well as for large areas of nubari dhurra planted on sahels and river islands, with the exception of small areas in Assouan province and isolated sahels and islands, which can only be flooded in years of very high levels. The whole land in Upper Egypt will be irrigated and the discharge of the basins in the Southern Provinces will begin on October 5th, and in Assiont and Minieh provinces on October 10th. The flood, though late in its earlier stages, has been satisfactory for the irrigation of the basin lands in Upper Egypt, and at the same time the levels in Lower Egypt have been suitable for passing away the flood withoat endangering the Nile banks.

div.head: PLAGUE AT SUEZ.
div.p: The plague at Suez is apparently increasing, especially in the Rue Colmar, the principal street of the town. Europeans are beginning to take the matter seriously, and by this morning's train five well-known families left harriedly for Ismailia, and other places in order to avoid the danger.

Suspected cases of plague and fully diagnosed cases are conveyed by the authorities to the isolation wooden huts in the desert, in a large covered cart styled an "ambalance," which is the terror of the people. The majority of the Europeans have made up their minds to absolutely refuse at any sacrifice to be taken away in this manner, and owing to the agitation of the people, all the Consuls will hold a meeting next Tuesday morning to thoroughly look into the matter, and to arrange for the comfort of the people.

If the sanitary authorities were to provide a suitable ambulance to convey the people to the huts, I think the matter would be taken more calmly by the public. Owing to the fact that the majority of the cases have proved fatal in the isolation huts, the general opinion is that these huts are not adapted to Europeans, owing to their being exposed to the sun.

It is strange to see that in localities which have been disinfected fresh cases of plague occur, and it seems to be the general opinion that the disinfection, and especially the whitewashing of the walls ought to be done better.
Suez was once considered to be the healthiest town in Egypt, but of late the contrary has been the case.

div.head: SHOCKING MURDER AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: A marder of a peculiarly atrocious character was committed in the Karmous quarter of Alexandria last Saturday afternoon. A young Greek went to the residence of his aunt whom he knew kept her savings, amounting to about £150, in her house, and asked her to lend him £20. The old lady refused to part with the money, so the youth drew his dagger and proceeded deliberately to plunge it again and again into her face and bosom until she expired. The murderer then ransacked the house, and at last succeeded in discovering the hoard. There upon he made off, and has not been seen since.

div.head: THE MAHMOUDIEH TRAGEDY.
div.p: It is now stated that the murdered girl whose body was found in the Mahmoudieh Canal at Alexandria on Wednesday last, was a Copt from Minieh, as a mamour in that moudirieh has announced the disappearance of a female of this race. Attached to the sack in which the corpse was found was a cat, which a careful examination has shown was killed evidently by the same instrument as inflicted the wound on the girl.

div.head:
LONDON'S LORD MAYOR.
SIR WILLIAM TRELOAR.
div.p: Sir William Treloar has been elected Lord Mayor of London. (Reuter)

Sir William Purdy Treloar, Kt., who, as announced in the above telegram, will take over the reins of magisterial government of the City of London from the Rt. Hon. Walter Vaughan Morgan on the 9th of November, was born on January 13, 1843, and was the second son of the late Thomas Treloar, of Helston, Cornwall. He was educated at King's College Sohool and as a young man he took a great interest in the municipalism of London. In 1880 he was elected a member of the Corporation of the City of London, and in 1891 he was appointed chairman of the Commissioners of Sewers. From 1899 to 1900 he was one of the Sheriffs of London ; he was knighted before the expiration of his term of office, and since then he has been alderman for the ward of Farrington Without. He is the principal of the firm of Treloar and Sons, the well known cocoa-nut fibre manufacturers and importers of Turkish carpets, and is a director and trustee of Thomas Cook and Son, Egypt, Ltd. Sir William Treloar is a great reader; he takes a great interest in journalism and is a member of the Savage and Press clubs. He is the author of "Ludgate Hill, Past and Present" and "Prince of Palma."

div.head:
ACCUSATION OF COWARDICE.
ALY BEY'S REPLY.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,—I was much astonished at reading the the letter contributed to your esteemed paper of yesterday by a disguished writer who pretended to have been present at my trial before a General Court Martial at Abbassieh in the spring of 1896 where nobody is allowed to be present besides the members of the Court.
I have been tried at the War Office and not at Abbassieh as what your correspondent surmised.

This disguised gentleman is, as I believe him to be, an inspired person by "Al Mokattam," if he is not one of his editors, the paper which first wrote on this subject touching the same points wrongly.
When I explained the true circumstances of my case, in the reply, the controversy was dropt down in the Arabic papers and renewed, by its first manufacturers as I believe, in your esteemed paper.
My reply in the "Al Lewa" of the 25th inst. was as follows:—

I had tendered my resignation on Sunday the 8th of March 1896 and the announcement of the orders issued to the effect of mobilising the Sudan Expedition was made on the 15th of March after H.H. the Khedive's return from the Mosque of Amr on Friday the 13th of March when His Highness presided the Council of the Ministers held on that day to decide on the despatching of the Sudan Expedition.

If "Al Mokattam" desires to know my case well, it may ask H. E. Mohammed Zohry Pasha who was a member in the General Court Martial, held at the War Office on the 21st of March 1896 for my trial and who was one of the great opponents to the decision of the court when H. E. read the date of the postal seal impressed on the envelope containing my application for resignation and became sure that I addressed the letter to the War Office a week before the announcement for despatching the expedition to Dongola was made public and even before it was discussed by the Council of Ministers,

If this does not suffice those who think that they can not defend the Syrians whom we esteem so much, but by insulting others, we shall be obliged to add a new page to Mr. Blunt's "Atrocities of Justice" in defence of the truth.—Yours truly,
Aly Fahmy.
Cairo, September 31st.
[We can assure Aly Bey Fahmy that the correspondent to whom he refers has no connection in any way whatever with "Al Mokattam. " Ed. E. G ]

div.head: ESBEKIEH GARDENS.
div.p: By king permission of Lt.-Col. C.J. Markham and Officers, the Band of the 1st Battalion King's Royal Rifles will perform the following selection of music at the Esbekieh Gardens to morrow evening from 9 p.m. till 11 p.m.
Thomas Brown, Bandmaster.

div.head:
STOP PRESS EDITION.
BRITISH STEAMER ON FIRE.
div.p: the British S.S. Antonio is on fire in the quarantine grounds at Mex. The conflagration is serious.

div.head:
THE FINANCE MINISTRY.
CHITTY BEY'S APPOINTMENT.
div.p: We hear on good authority that the following important changes in the Ministry of Finance will take place in the course of the next three months. Chitty Bey will finally leave the Customs, and will take up a post in the Ministry of Finance, which has yet to be named, but will probably bear with it the title of Controller General of the Budget. It is stated that the Controller General will be direotly responsible to the Minister of Finance and the Financial Adviser. The place which Chitty Bey has so worthily and so succesfally filled at Alexandria will in all probability be taken by Mr. A. King Lewis, Controller of the Department of Direct Taxation, whose great ability and energy are vouched for by all who are competent to give an opinion on the working of the Ministry of Finance, though little known to the publio owing to Mr. King Lewis' happy lack of any capacity for self advertisement. Another able official, Mr. J. Haines, of the same Ministry, is named as Mr. King Lewis' successor.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: Leave of absence has been granted to :— El Kaimakam Clayton Bey, senior inspector, Kassala province, until the 6th inst. Extension of leave has been granted to El Kaimakam McBarnet Bey, M.V.O., D.S.O., Cavalry, until the 15th prox., and to El Bimbashi Moore, Staff Officer, Hired Transport, until the 6th. prox. El Kaimakam Sorel-Cameron Bey has been granted extension of leave until the 26th of September owing to ill health. El Miralai Palmer Bey, and El Miralai Sutherland Bey, Financial Secretary, E. A., and O. C., Bahr el Ghazal District, have returned from leave.

Captain F J M. Postlethwaite, The King's Own (Yorkshire Light Infantry), having reported his arrival in Egypt from Gibraltar, is taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army from the 4th September, 1906, with the rank of Bimbashi,and is posted to the 4th Battalion. El Bimbashi B. Lamb, 15th Sudanese, has been transferred to the Sudan Government.

div.head: OMDURMAN HERO DEAD.
div.p: With full military honours the funeral took place at Heston, Middlesex, last week, of Private James Foy, of the 21st Lancers, who met with his death whilst playing in a football match last Saturday by sustaining a rupture of the intestine in a fall. Private Foy had served 14 years with the 21st Lancers. He went through the Egyptian campaign ; took part in the celebrated charge at Omdurman ; and held the medal for the action and the Khartoum clasp. A pathetic feature of Private Foy's death is that when he met with his fatal accident he was about to purchase his discharge from the Army. He was one of the best football players in the regiment, and for the last five years he kept goal for the regimental team.

div.head: AGRICULTURAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: The Agricultural Bank of Egypt announces that Coupon No. 4 of the three-and-a-half per cent. bonds and the scrip coupon of the three- and-a-half per cent. guaranteed bonds will be paid, on and after October 1, at the offices of the London agency of the National Bank of Egypt, 4 and 5, King William-street, E C.

div.head: UM RUS GOLD MINES OF EGYPT.
div.p: The report states that to Sept. 18 the total number of shares allotted was 133,849, the whole of which are credited as 15s. paid up, as part oonsideration for the transfer of the assets of the Um Rus Gold Mines of Egypt (Ltd.) (old company) as provided by the terms of the reconstruction agreement. Up to date, the total amount of cash received by the company in respect of the said 133,849 shares is £12,577. With a view to augmenting the reserves of ore, and thereby enabling the monthly output to be increased to the full capaoity of the mill, it has been decided to temporarily suspend milling operations, and to push forward the development of the mine as vigorously as possible.

div.head: NEW SECONDARY SCHOOL.
div.p: The new Cairo secondary school, which will be known as the Saidieh, will be opened in the course of the week. Sixteen pupils have applied for admittance. We understand that a number of boys will migrate from the Khedivieh. The school buildings near Gizeh being still unfinished, one of the palaces near the Nasrieh school will be used for the time. The Saidieh school will accommodate two boys when in full working order. Mr. A. H. Sharman, the popular and successful headmaster of the Khedivieh School, will be the first headmaster of the Saidieh.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Tabor sailed on Saturday afternoon for Liverpool, with passengers mails and general cargo including 4,917 bales of cotton.
The Messageries Maritimes mail-boat Portugal, which left Marseilles last Thursday afternoon, passed through the Straits of Messina on Saturday afternoon and is due at Alexandria to-morrow morning.

div.head:
EGYPT'S "PATRIOT."
DEMAND FOR NATIONAL UNIVERSITY
div.p: Mustapha Kamel has written to Farid Bey, suggesting the formation of a National University which would unite all Egyptians and strengthen the national sentiment. He invites the Egyptian nation to realise this grand work.
(Havas)
Mustapha Pasha Kamel embarks at Marseilles for Egypt on the 10th inst., and "Al Lewa" will appear on the 15th inst. in a permanent eight page edition.
It is rumoured that the Pasha is contemplating the purchase of one of the most important European daily newspapers in Cairo.
The servioes of a former French journalist at Cairo are to be engaged for the French portion of the paper.
The English part will be under the control of an Irish Nationalist journalist. This gentleman is expected shortly.

Many members of Parliament have promised the Pasha to favour his new English newspaper with articles. Pierre Loti, Commandant Marchand, Mme Juliette Adam and other well known French personages are collaborating in the French edition of "Al Lewa."

div.head: MR. BLUNT'S BOOK.
div.p: The criticism by Mr. Moberly Bell to which "Al Mokattam" refers, as noted in our issue of Saturday appears in a letter of the "Times" signed "Your Correspondent in Egypt 1865-1890." It runs as follows"
Sir,—Will you allow me to recall, and to me as a warning, some Egyptian history of 25 years ago ?

In the year 1881 there was a beginning of trouble in Egypt—it was a cloud no bigger than a man's hand—a military riot in Cairo barely noticed in your columns. There had been another, apparently more serious, three years before ; but, though it produced a change of Ministry, and eventually the deposition of Ismail, it had been followed by no disorder,and there was no reason to suppose that this insubordination of three Egyptian colonels would have serious consequences.

But then, as now, the danger was not from Egypt, but from London. There is a class of Englismen who have adopted as their motto "Against our country whether right or wrong," and because we had already become partly responsible for order in Egypt, Mr. Wilfrid Soawen Blunt felt called upon to make himself the spokesman and supporter of whatever elements of disorder might exist in that country.

It is not too muoh to say that the whole Egyptian question of 1881-2, with all its consequences, ostensibly directed by Arabi and largely assisted by the incompetence of the British Government, was due to the mischievous interference of Mr. Wilfrid Blant, who, on the failure of his hopes after the loss of many thousands of lives, consoled himself by making it the subject of a poem.

Had the matter ended there, perhaps there might not have been much cause for lament. The achievements of England in Egypt have in that quarter of a century been so magnificent and benefioent that, even apart from the production of that poem, they might well be worth the purchase at the price of some blood and treasure.
But, unfortunately, that poem contained a a prophecy. Mr. Blunt was not content with apostrophizing his victims: —
I oare not if you fled, . . .
It may be you were cowards. Let them prove it.
What matter ?

He was not content with announcing from his armchair that he himself would "rather fly with the first craven" than "head the hottest charge." As a matter of fact, he did neither, but he felt that the mantle of the prophet was upon him, and, addressing his own countrymen, he said :—
Thou wentest to this Egypt for thy pleasure.
Thou shalt remain with her for thy sore pain.
Thou hast possessed her beauty. Thou wouldst leave her.
Nay—thou shalt lie with her as thou hast lain.
She shall bring shame upon thy face with all men.
She shall disease thee with her grief and fear.
Thou shalt grow sick and feeble in her ruin.
Thou shalt repay her to the last sad tear.

Well, a quarter of a century has elapsed and the prophecy remains not only unfulfilled, but very gloriously disproved. This is naturally exasperating to a prophetic poet, but again today there is another cloud no bigger than a man's hand, and, mindful of past achievements, Mr. Blunt's hopes rise. Again he struggles to convert chaos out of order; again he risks the sacrifice of more British blood and treasure— perhaps again to find a subject for a poem.

If we may judge from Sir Edward Grey's declarations, the Liberal Ministry of 1906 will not make the same fatuous blunder as their predecessors of 1881. But, lest they should do so, it may be useful that they should read these extracts from your files of 21 years ago.
In "The Times" of September 29, 1885, I wrote:—

Two men, each doubtless equally honest and equally injudicious, must share between them the responsibility for these earlier incidents of our operations in Egypt—Mr. Blunt, who assured Arabi that Mr. Gladstone was not in earnset, and Mr. Gladstone, who was only in earnest when it was too late.
In "The Times" of October 2, 1885, you published a correspondence from which I make the following extracts :—
Mr. Gladstone to Mr. Blunt, September 29, 1885:—

My reason for declining to answer you is that I am reluctant to say what I think as to your conduct in Egypt—I means as to its character and effect, for I do not question its motives. Were Arabi Pasha to invite me to a controversy I should have to make a similar answer.
Mr. Blunt to Mr. Gladstone, Setember 30, 1885:—

When the acount is drawn up between us, as it must be some day, in regard to events so tragic in the world's history as the bombardment of Alexandria, the massacres of June and July, Arabi's trial, your broken promises to Egypt, and Gordon's death, I do not fear that honest men will hold me in any way your debtor.
Mr. Blnnt's poem was entitled "The Wind and the Whirlwind." He sowed the wind—much wind; he reaped the reproach alike of those he opposed and of those he supported.

div.head:
THE LATE MAJOR JOHNSTONE.
DEATH AFTER AN OPERATION.
div.p: Farther details concerning the death of Major L'Estrange Johnstone, which have been telegraphed from London to the Board of the State Railways Administration by Colonel Western, prove that the supposition that death was due to an accident was erroneous, and that he succumbed to a sudden illness which had necessitated the performance of an operation.

The week before last Major Johnstone, says the telegram referred to, felt seedy and he consulted a specialist. On Monday he entered a nursing home to prepare for the operation which had been decided upon. This was performed on Wednesday, but he died on on Thursday evening.
The funeral will take place to morrow at Alya, Sterling.
A memorial service in memory of the late General Manager of State Railways will be held at All Saints' Church, Cairo, on Wednesday at 6 p.m.
A correspondent writes from Cairo : —

Universal and sincere regret was expressed on every side when the news of the untimely death of Major L'Estrange Johnstone became known in Cairo, and wherever Englishmen met together the sad tidings were the topic of conversation. To him is due to a large extent the efficiency of the railway service of which Egypt can now boast. I do not mean to suggest that the service is on parallel with that of European countries, but it will be granted by all that the progress which has been effected in the Railway Administration is equal to that of any administration. You remarked in your issue of Saturday that Major Johnstone could not be considered as an administrator of the first rank, and such, indeed, was the case, but by his indomitable energy he overcame many of the obstacles which oppose responsible officialdom in Egypt. He instituted many reforms and during his seven yean of presidency steady progress was made.

He was admired, respected, and even beloved by those who worked under him,and he succeeded in gaining the confidence of the native employés of every grade. His consideration for and great kindness to his employés gained for him great popularity, and all feel that they have lost a kind friend as well as a lenient master.

div.head: PERSONAL AND, SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Kamal-el-Din and Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha arrived this morning at Alexandria by the Austrian Lloyd mail boat on their return from Europe.
Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha leaves for Cairo about the middle of the month.
The Gaekwar of Baroda and the Maharani, with their suite, are arriving at Port Said shortly from England.
The Countess of Cromer will return to Cairo a few weeks after the Earl of Cromer has gone back. She is expected to travel by the Derbyshire, which leaves Marseilles on Nov. 2.
Mr. M. de C. Findlay, the British Chargé d'Affaires, paid an official visit to Fakhry Pasha yesterday.
Sir William Garstin is leaving England for Egypt in the P. and O. steamer Marmora, which sails from Marseilles on October 12.
Sir William is at present staying at Eserick.
Rear Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, Director General of the Ports and Lighthoases Administration, and Lady Blomfield are arriving by the Orient Liner due at Port Said on the 30th inst.
H. E. Mohamed Pasha Mohsen is leaving Alexandria to-morrow in order to visit his estates at Shebrakeit, in the Behera Province, He will be away for about five days.
During his recent visit to England Sir Vincent Corbett, the Financial Adviser, stayed for a few days with Sir Ernest Cassel at the latter's place at Newmarket.
Miralai Hopkinson Bey, Commandant of the Alexandria City Police, is expected to return to Alexandria on the 18th inst.
Ibrahim Pasha Neguib leaves for Cairo to-day.

Captain Seymour Clarke Bull, of Carlisle, Cumberland, formerly of Cairo, Egypt, and late of the Inniskilling Dragoons, who was killed as the result of an affray with the villagers at Denishwai, on June 13, aged 32, left estate valued at £2,331 gross and probate of his will has been granted to his mother, Mn. Fanny Bull.
Mr. Wynch, Manager of the National Bank in Khartoum, left last night for the Sudan.
El Bimbashi H.M. Greaves, Upper Nile district, has been transferred to the Sudan Government.
Mohamed Effendi Tohamy, formerly headmaster ot Nekhla Sohool, has been transferred to a similar position at Quesna.
The Rev. A. H. Lougley, B. A., Assistant Chaplain at St Marks', Alexandria, will arrive to morrow by the Messageries Maritimes S.S. Portugal,

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)
Aujourd'hui nous avons ans reprise générale et sensible, déterminée par la hausse des cotons et les rachats da découvert.
On remarque en particulier la National Bank qui atteint 26 15/16 acheteurs, en gain d'une demi-livre.
La Cassa di Sconto gagne 4 francs 50 à 226 1/2 l'ancienne ; la nouvelle s'avance à 219 3/4.
De 17 5/16 les Nungovich Hotels montent à 17 1/2, la Nile Land de 14 13/16 à 16 1/8, et la part de fondateurComptoir de 43 à 44 livres.

Voilà pour les fluctuations les plus importantes. Mais il y a hausse également de l'Àgricole à 9 23/32, de la Delta Light à 11 3/4, des Tramways d'Alexandrie à 187 1/2 les privilégiées et 340 les dividendes, des Markets à 26, de la Sait & Soda à 21/6, de la Khédivial Mail Ordinary à 34/6, du Comptoir à 6 21/32 l'ancienne et 6 7/16 la nouvelle.
L'Union Foncière est très demandée à 6 livres.
Bref, la poussée est générale et telle que nous n'en avions pas vu depuis longtemps d'aussi importantes.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien AVIS
div.p: L'Administration a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Pablic qu'elle recevra jusqu'au 15 Novembre prochain à midi des offres pour fournitures de bureau pour l'année 1907 conformément aux échantillons déposés aux Magasins Généraux à Boulac (Caire) et à Gabbary ( Alexandrie) ou l'on peut obtenir copie da cahier des charges contre paiement de 150 m/ms. (cent cinquante millièmes). Les soumissionnaires doivent verser à la Caisse Centrale de l'Administration une garantie provisoire égale à 5% du montant de leurs offres et dont reçu devra être attaché à celles-ci.
Les offres devront être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de 30 millièmes. Elles seront adressées par la poste sous pli recommandé à :
Monsieur le Directeur des Magasins,
Chemins de fer de l'Etat, Boulac (Caire),
et sous double enveloppe l'intérieure portant la suscription suivante:
"Offre pour fournitures de bureau."
L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter l'offre la plus basse ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées; elle se réserve le droit de diviser la commande.
Le Caire, le 29 Septembre 1906. 28595-2-1

div.head:
AMERICAN COTTON LOSS.
ESTIMATE OF 3,000,000 DOLLARS

div.p: Twenty per cent, of the cotton crop in some sections of Mississippi has been damaged owing to the storms and floods. Mobile is the chief sufferer. The entire business section is five feet deep in water. Several blocks of buildings have been swept away. Damage has been done to the extent of 3,000,000 dollars. Fifty persons have perished. (Reuter)

Every house along a 10 mile water-front at Pensacola has been wrecked by the hurricane. Thirty miles of the railway have been washed away. About 75 persons have perished, most of whom are negroes. Eight steamers have been sunk. (Reuter)
Ten thousand persons are homeless in Pensacola. The forts and naval station are badly damaged. (Reuter)
A detachment of United States marines have been landed in order to guard the Treasury.

An American provisional Government has assumed possession of Cuba. Mr. Taft has formally proclaimed himself Governor. He declares that the Government has only been undertaken on account of the necessities of the situation, and for the sole purpose of restoring peace, order, and public confidence until a permanent Government has been established.
Mr. Taft's action is the result of the failure of the Caban Congress to elect a successor to President Palma. (Reuter)
A provisory American Government has been proclaimed at Cuba. ( Havas)
President Roosevelt has ordered 6,000 troops to proceed to Cuba immediately. (Reuter) Havana, September 30.
Mr. Taft has released the political prisoners.
The Cubans are showing no signs of opposition to the action of the United States, (R.)
Two penniless Russian Jews, who were detained at Grimsby under the Aliens Act, confessed themselves to be bomb throwers from Warsaw. They were allowed to enter as political refugees. (Reuter)
Prince Constantin has officially invested M. Zaimis as High Commissioner of Crete. M. Zaimis will leave to-morrow. (Havas)

M. Zaimis was formally invested with the Commissionership of Crete in the presence of the Crown Prince, M. Theotokis, and representatives of the four protecting Powers. M. Zaimis will leave to-morrow for Crete. (R.)
Seven thousand ironworkers in the Clyde have gone on strike for a rise in wages. A prolonged fight is probable. (Reuter)
The total revenue of the United Kingdom for the half year amounts to £63,095,382, being an increase over 1905 of £1,650,674. (Reuter)
Eighty Sikh police refused to go on duty on Saturday. They were disarmed and confined to barracks. (Reuter)
The last batch of Chinese coolies to be imported to the Rand has arrived here. (R.)
The authorities are now making spasmodic efforts to prevent a massacre. (Reuter)

div.head:
GERMANY ON THE NILE.
THE KAISER'S SCHEMES IN EGYPT.
div.p: With reference to the article which appeared in your issue of August 28, writes a correspondent from Cairo to the "Pall Mall Gazette," under the heading of "German Trading Energy," the impression in Egypt of the advances made by Germany in this country, is that the German Government is at the back of all these ventures. First came the direct line from Hamburg to Alexandria, followed by the facilities offered by the Hamburg-American, Norddeutscher Lloyd, and Deutsch Ost-Afrika Lines; then the combine between the Hamburg-American and the Anglo-American Nile Navigation Company ; and the latest is the establishment of the Deutsche Orient-Bank in Cairo.

I know as a fact that about eighteen months ago one of the German lines made desperate efforts to under quote their English competitors and secure a hold on the shipments to Egypt. It actually went so far as to quote a mining syndicate a rate from London to Upper Egypt at the same price as it would cost to transport the material from Alexandria to Upper Egypt. This rate included conveyance from London to Hamburg, where trans-shipment into the direct steamers was to be effected. Thus, the German line would have taken the shipments, which were pretty considerable, from London to Alexandria, viâ Hamburg, free—it would have incurred a loss on the working expenses for those trips, besides paying out of its own pocket for the freight from London to Hamburg. At present, too, the rates from Germany to Egypt are ridiculously low, and all this would go to prove the truth of the statement in your article of August 28, that £100,000 had been lost in the Mediterranean in the last two years alone.

It is pretty generally admitted, too, that the combine on the Nile was a political move. No doubt the step will increase the business done by that company—all the Germans and German Americans, who formerly divided their patronage, will naturally give it now to the new amalgamated service, but it is understood, that as a strictly commercial enterprise, it is not attaining the success that was hoped. In this instance it was plainly the ambitions desire of the German Government to have the German flag floating on the Nile that led to this deal, and since the intimate friendship between the directors of the Hamburg-American Line and the Kaiser and his advisers is well known, it has not been difficult to put two and two together.

The establishment of the Deutsche Orient Bank in Cairo is also a political move. At, the time it was announced that the principal German banks were interested ; the Deutsche Levante Line, which trades between Germany and Egypt, has great interests in this new bank. All these ventures are intimately in-woven, and are a series of wheels within wheels in a definite plan, which has the German Government at the back of it.

When the time comes for Great Britain to introduce important reforms in the higher administration of Egypt, when the time comes for England to take the country under her direct control (as is confidently expected here at an early date), then Germany will step in and say : "We have extensive interests in Egypt, which we cannot allow to be overlooked. We have steamers flying your flag on the Nile; through our bank we have a good deal of commercial influence throughout the country ; besides which our trade with Egypt is no small consideration. We do not want to obstruct your reforms, but unless you give us a quid pro quo in the Near East (the Bagdad Railway or Persian Gulf) we shall claim a conference to inquire into the Egyptian question, or shall do our best to hinder our efforts"—or some such argument. And if we get our own way without any concession on our part, it will be due solely to the ability of our diplomats, for it is incontestably certain that it is Germany's object to be able to say that she has certain interests in Egypt, and so bring pressure to bear for concessions in other parts. The Germans are smart business men ; they do not usually run commercial enterprises at a loss without some very good reason, at any rate. And in this case the German Government and its subsidy are the very good reason. The trend of affairs is being watched with interest, and the ultimate outcome of the present German ventures, although generally anticipated, is being eagerly looked forward to.

div.head: CATERPILLAR'S STRANGE ABODE.
div.p: In making a post-mortem examination of a boarded-out infant that died while in the care of a registered nurse at North Melbourne, says the "British Australasian," Dr. Mollison recently found a living caterpillar in a large intestine. It is supposed that it was swallowed with food, either in its existing form or as an egg. Dr. Mollison put forward a novel, yet probable, solution of the story. He said that very likely the child had swallowed an egg, or eggs, of a butterfly, or of a moth, and that the heat of the body had completed the work of incubation. The curiosity has been forwarded for examination to the Government entomologist.

div.head: CYPRUS.
div.p: ''My Experiences of the Island of Cyprus." By B. Stewart. With Photographs. London : Skeffington and Son. 6s.

Mr. Stewart has written an interesting book on Cyprus, and indeed no mind with a sense for history and legend could fail to be inspired by an island whose annals incarnate all the romance of the Crusades. Crete, perhaps, has had a more exciting, or at least a more heroic, history; but the conquerors who succeeded each other through the centuries left there no monuments of their genius to compare with the castles and churches of Cyprus.

The Cretan themselves, who march about with a pride born of their secular struggle for freedom, are certainly a more interesting race than the Cypriotes. But they have no memories of Cœur de Lion and Guy de Lusignan. Crete is certainly very beautiful, but it has, on the whole, the climate and landscape of Southern Europe, and the traveller who goes aboard at Marseilles feels no shook of surprise on landing at Suda. Cyprus, on the other hand, though it is by race and history a Greek island, belongs geographically to Syria. It is this strange combination of an architecture which belongs to Gothic Europe and a climate that recalls Palestine which makes its strange and peculiar charm. Mr. Stewart writes well on both subjects. He is an engineer, and all his pages on the natural phenomena on the island, its agriculture, and its material needs are decidedly intelligent and informing. His descriptions of the architecture are also clear and good.

With the inhabitants, unfortunately, he has less sympathy, and sees in their Greek patriotism only so much sedition, which a really strong Government would repress with a ruthless hand. He does not explain, however, by what process we acquired a title to the devotion of their island when we took it as a sort of pledge against Russian aggression on the Black Sea and saddled them for the privilege with an annual tribute to the Porte. But Mr. Stewart is under no illusions about the weak points of our rule. The revenue of the island is only £170,000 per annum, and even with our grant-in-aid of some £30,000 it has to pay about £60,000 yearly to the Turkish bond-holders. We have done a very little to develop it of late, but nothing which at all balances the expenses of an English administration. The irrigation system is a partial failure, the new railway is ill placed, the harbours are neglected, and the whole commerce of the island is paralysed by the want of quick communication with the Egyptian market. Mr. Chamberlain tried to do something to justify our rule. But 1rs efforts, tactful and well-meaning though they were, have not compensated for a quarter of a century of neglect and over-taxation.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON AT MANCHESTER.
div.p: In reference to a recent report from the Alexandria General Produce Association as to the exports from Alexandria during the season 1905-06, in which it is stated that Manchester has made a new record in her imports of Egyptian cotton with 185,128 bales against 153,956 bales the previous season, a correspondent of the "Manchester Guardian" points out that the actual figures of imports of Egyptian cotton to Manchester for the season 1905-6 were 212,257 bales, which compares with 183,297 bales in the previous season. So, instead of Manchester receiving less than half of the importations to Great Britain, as shown by the figures of the Alexandria General Produce Association, this port has received considerably more than half.

The London correspondent of the same journal, adverting to the rivalry between the ports of Liverpool and Manchester, says : About Liverpool's grievances against Manchester the latest I hear in London shipping quarters is that the Egyptian cotton for Boston which formerly went by Liverpool is now being transhipped at Manchester.

div.head: AN INTERESTING INCIDENT.
div.p: Considering the Sultan's views as to the proper position of women, a little incident that occured when the Kaiser visited Constantinople acquires significance. The Saltan, who, as is well-known, never leaves Yildiz Kiosk except to go to prayers on Friday at noon, proposed to send various high dignitaries to receive the Kaiser as he stepped on the shore of the Bosphorus at the official landing place. The Kaiser required that the Sultan must come and receive him in person ; and the Sultan had to yield, for he keenly desired the glory in Mohamedan eyes of having a European sovereign come to pay his respects to the Commander of the Faithful, and it was intimated to him that personal welcome at the shore was an indispensable condition. The Sultan was waiting, then, to receive the Emperor as he stepped from his boat ; and two carriages were in readiness, one to convey the two sovereigns, and one for the Empress. The Kaiser overturned the arrangement by putting the Empress into the first carriage with the Sultan, while he himself occupied the second. So it came about that the Saltan endured the indescribable humiliation of driving through the streets of his own capital before the eyes of his Mohamedan subjects, sitting side by side with a Giaour woman. Such is the story that is told. I had not the good fortune to be there to see. Nothing could be more humiliating to the Sultan than that situation ; and the most effective counterblast to his Pan-Islamic propaganda would be to circulate through all Islam the description of that carriage drive, if any Mohamedan could be induced to believe it. The Sultan himself will not forget, when the time comes, that the friendship of Germany ashn ot been an unalloyod pleasure. (' Contemporary Review.")

div.head: INTERNATIONAL ORDER OF GOOD TEMPLARS. WEDDING FESTIVITIES AT CAIRO.
div.p: On Wednesday evening last a most interesting event took place at the British Consulate, Cairo, the occasion being the marriage of Rifleman Hanet, 1st King's Royal Rifles, to Miss M. E. Ogden. Lt.-Cpl Robinson and Miss A. Watson, acted as best man and bridesmaid at the ceremony.

In order to show their appreciation, the members of the Inniskilling Excelsior Lodge No. 109, in conjunction with the I. O. R. and friends, held a social to entertain the happy couple. Both are members of the above Lodge, and since their initiation have taken a keen interest in Templary generally.
Refreshments were provided, and full justice having been done to the good things, the room was cleared and a most successful social followed.

Bro Brown, on behalf of Inniskilling Excelsior Lodge: I give you a hearty welcome to this Lodge on your happy event. Yon have been earnest workers during your membership here, and I trust you may be long spared to continue your good work.

"It is very gratifying to see a young couple start life as total abstainers, instead of what we are usually accustomed to—drunkenness. I trust many members may follow your example, by having a sober, and sensible wedding. I am sure all the members heartily join with me in wishing you every success in your future lives. I now call on you to drink the health of the bride and bridegroom in the only beverage God has provided, viz., "pure water" (Cheers). Their healths were drunk amid applause. Bro Brown then called on Bro Gervine, Blue Caps Pride Lodge, to preside.
The chairman in the course of his remarks congratulated the happy couple on their marriage.

"I thank you Bros of Excelsior Lodge for asking me to preside, and moreover I am very pleased to be once more amongst you for a shot time. The event just celebrated is one to which we will all look back with pride, inasmuch as it has been celebrated in a manner altogether at variance with the numerous festivals we are accustomed to.

Strong drink predominates, the event usually culminating in a "free fight." But at present Irishmen and Englishmen too are beginning to realise, and as it were open their eyes to the fact that drinking whether in military or civil life did not pay and we as good Templars had to congratulate ourselves on the great strides that have been made in the last decade.

There cannot be any doubt that within the next generation the municipal authorities will have control of the drink traffic, and "local veto will be the order of the day" (hear bear). In wishing Mr and Mrs Hanett every happiness, the only recompense required by good templars was that they remained faithful to the principles they espoused, that they would work as assiduously in the future as in past, and thereby solidify and augment the order to which they were all so proud to belong (cheers).
The groom (Bro Harriett) in a few words thanked them for their complimentary remarks, and said he would do all ill his power to promote the good cause (cheers).

The following contributed to the programme. Sister Mrs. Hanett. Bro. Cpl. Gervine, R. D. Fusrs, Bro.*. Taston, 1st Lanc. Fusrs, Bro.*. Ferguson, Bro.'. Grant, Bro.*. Skirt, Bro.*. Carter, Bro.*. Robinson, and K.R.R.'s Bro.*. Kerr, Bro.*. Young, Bro.*. Shaw, Bro.*. Noy, R. E, Bro.*. McClung, Bro.*. Brown.
Dancing was kept up till about 12.30, when the chairman announced the termination of the programme.
Bro.*. Brown C.I., proposed a vote of thanks to the chairman for presiding which was seconded by Bro.*, Beatty and carred amid deafening applause.
The chairman thanked them for their kind remarks and trusted they would soon meet again to consolidate the union already existing between the Lodges.
Bro.*. Beatty conveyed to the happy couple the best wishes of the Excelsior Lodge and trusted they would have long life and happiness.

Mrs. Hanett thanked the members and friends for the pains they had taken to make them happy,—words failed her to convey fully her heart—felt thanks, and in the name of her husband she wished them success (Cheers).
The chairman suitably replied and the procedings terminated with the singing of "for they are jolly good fellows" followed by the National Anthem.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB.
div.p: The Committee have decided to consider the races for European English horses as not sufficiently filled, and in consequence they will all be left open until 1st January 1907. Subscriptions and nominations will close at that date. Existing subscriptions will hold good.
All the remaining big races for 1907 will take place as published.
Walter O. Wilkinson. Secretary.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in the spirit of fair play to all, to permit--within certain necessary limits--free discussion.

div.head: THE HIBERNIAN PATRIOT.
div.p: To the Editor of the-"Egytian Gazette."

Sir,—In your issue of the 14th inst I notice that the Camel driver of the "Al Lewa" is to be an "Hibernian patriot," and from other sources, I have learnt that Gaelic is also to appear in this famous paper.

The Celtic editor is a well-known Highland sportsman, named Donaldus Ex terra Mac A lister Dhue, from Ben Macdui, whose sires, in accordance with the writings of an old fabulous Coptic scribe, named Kamel ebn Khatam, were in Egypt in the antediluvian period, carrying on war against the giants of Anubis when the North Sea or German Oman was frozen over. I may as well quote a word or two here. "Donald Gorm Mac Alister Dhue with 800 followers from Greenland's icy mountains to India's coral strands on foot in 800 days and nights with nothing but oatmeal from the Pictish country and dates from Egypt carried on Camel." Kind readers, imagine what a chorus we are going to have when the "Al Lewa" appears with English, simplified in American style, and Gaelic for the sake of euphony. The Celtic editor, Mr. Biles, Mr. Kamel Pasha, Mr. Robinson Mac Kimon, and Mr. Hardi Kerr, have been invited for a few days' hunting in the Scottish mountains. Mr. Hardi Kerr, and Mr. Kamel will look rather fanny in their kilts, sporans, and glengarry bonnets dancing the sword dance among the hills. An Egyptian geomancer said that Mr. Tonald Kamel was shortly to be a Presbyterian, being already reported as a "German subject." I presume that the Revd. Saint

Peter of Alexandria will next declare that he pegged Kamel's conscience before leaving the land of the Pharaohs, but the "Scotch intrigue" completed the work. I am preparing a banquet for the Celtic editor, and, I think for the sake of old Ireland, the English editor should be entertained. No doubt Mr. Kamel will be looked up by the Rev. Saint Peter, who is going to baptize him with Scotch whisky in one of the hotels of Egypt, also Sheikh Blunt ebn Sheikh El Nadda, a terrible Bedouin warrior from Siwa Oasis, is to give a lecture at this feast. The (illegible) Tonald Kamel is leaving Egypt for Russia by order of the Rev. Saint Peter to convert the Jews, Sheikh Blunt, the Egyptian patriot, is to assist the Rev. Saint Peter in the purification of Alexandria and Cairo.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 90 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah, Zagazig, or Saida Zenab.
